item.item_label: Who is this course aimed at
When is unconscious bias most active?
How can you overcome your biases?

screen_id.keywords: Desk, Office, Work, Computer, PC, Keybord, Documents

screen.Content: Each year, 5.8 million people die from injuries, and cardiovascular disease and road accidents are major causes of death and disability. Learning basic first aid can save lives, and this First Aid for Adults course from the Red Cross and Red Crescent teaches essential skills to help those in need.

screen.Section: Who is this course aimed at
screen.Content: The course starts with the fundamentals of first aid and covers essential topics such as the recovery position, CPR, choking, stroke, bleeding, road accidents, burns, and psychological first aid. It also emphasizes key actions to prevent accidents, reinforcing that prevention is better than cure. Additionally, the course includes lessons on providing first aid safely during infectious disease outbreaks, such as COVID-19, and highlights the importance of staying updated with local guidance and evolving international standards.

This learning session is designed to teach you essential first aid skills for adults and their relevance in everyday emergencies. The lessons will help you act confidently to assist others and create a safer environment. Providing first aid can sometimes be stressful, but it is normal to feel anxious or uncertain. Seek support if needed, and be mindful of helping others safely. Before moving on to the core modules, you will learn key actions to respond effectively to accidents and medical emergencies.
Imagine walking down the street and seeing someone suddenly collapse. Your heart races, and you feel the urge to help—but what should you do first?

screen_id.keywords: Book, Page, 3D, Paper, Notes, Notepad, Notes, Document

screen.Content: Providing first aid can be challenging even for trained individuals. Emergencies are unpredictable, stressful, and often chaotic, requiring quick thinking and calmness under pressure.
People may feel anxious or freeze during emergencies, unsure of what to do. Hesitation can delay vital care and reduce the chances of a positive outcome.

Misjudging the Situation

 

It can be difficult to correctly assess the casualty’s condition under stress. Wrong decisions, such as misidentifying choking or unconsciousness, can worsen the situation.
Without regular practice, even trained individuals may forget how to perform CPR, choking relief, or the recovery position. Applying theory in real life can be more complicated than expected.
Attempting first aid incorrectly can accidentally harm the casualty. There is also a risk of injuring yourself while providing help.
Casualties may carry bloodborne pathogens or contagious illnesses. Special precautions, including gloves or masks, are needed, especially during pandemics like COVID-19.
Lack of a first aid kit or essential tools can make proper care difficult. Limited access to bandages, gloves, or antiseptics can hinder effective response.

Emergencies with several injured people require prioritization. Managing multiple casualties while ensuring your safety and coordinating bystanders adds extra stress.  

 

You may live thousands of miles away from Minneapolis, but racism is a global issue. It is not one that is merely confined to the United States - it is everywhere, and it is systemic.

High-pressure situations can cause fear, sadness, or panic. Emotional resilience is essential to stay calm and provide effective first aid.  This film of the actor John Boyega was shot at the London protests.
Uncertainty about what actions are legally allowed may cause hesitation. Fear of liability or making mistakes can prevent people from providing timely help.

screen_id.keywords: Silhouettes, Law, Negotiation, Business, People, Legal, Justice, Court, Protest, Hands, Banner

screen.Content: Racism can impact first aid by causing hesitation, unequal treatment, or biased decisions during emergencies, which can delay life-saving care. It may also create mistrust in those needing help, making communication harder and slowing response.
screen.Content_1: We can also protect ourselves and others by using basic safety measures. Wearing protective gear, reducing infection risks, and keeping essential first aid supplies close help us respond quickly and safely.

screen.Content:
What is unconscious bias?

 

Unconscious bias in first aid for adults means making quick judgments about someone without realizing it, based on their appearance, age, gender, or behavior. These hidden assumptions can affect how fast you help them and how seriously you take their symptoms. To give fair and safe care, first aiders should be aware of these biases and treat everyone equally by focusing only on their actual condition and needs.
As you can see, such biases can put innocent people in danger ...

screen_id.keywords: Silhouettes, Manager, Businessman, Thinking, Talking, Negotiation, Mediation, Consultation

screen.Content: Unconscious bias makes your brain form quick, automatic judgments without you noticing, which can affect how you treat others.
Psychologists say unconscious bias comes from the brain’s quick shortcuts, which can cause unintentional unfair judgments..
We use these judgments in first aid very quickly, but the ways we categorize or prioritize people are not always logical, evidence-based, or fair
These mental shortcuts can also lead to unconscious bias and affect the quality of decisions when providing first aids

screen_id.keywords: Silhouettes, Manager, Businessman, Businesswoman, Thinking, Talking, Negotiation, Mediation, Consultation

screen.Content: Have a look at this line up – at first glance, who do you think is likely to be a Chief Executive (click on one choice.)?
Studies show that most people pick 2 or 3 due to dress, age and even height.

Objective Leadership in First Aid

Did you know that studies show first aid responders sometimes favor people who look strong or healthy, even though in the general population, many adults may not appear that way? This unconscious preference can affect who receives attention first.
Strong first-aid leadership, supported by training and organizational backing, enhances teamwork, decision-making, and patient outcomes.
Judgments about appearance, age, or gender can cause responders to unconsciously favor some adults over others, even when medical need is equal.

screen_id.keywords: Silhouettes, Page, Document, Paper, Thinking, List

screen.Section: When is unconscious bias most active?
screen.Content:
When is unconscious bias most active?

Tick all that apply
screen.Content_1:
When you are:

Following clear procedures

Using objective data

Applying checklists or protocols

Relying on evidence-based guidelines

Being aware of personal biases

Reflecting before deciding

Using structured training systems

screen.Content: Bias is more likely to affect first aid responders when they are under stress, pressed for time, or distracted. It can also occur when responders act on autopilot without reflecting on their decisions or being mindful of their assumptions..
screen.Content_1:
When you are:

Following clear procedures

Using objective data

Applying checklists or protocols

Relying on evidence-based guidelines

Being aware of personal biases

Using structured training systems

screen_id.keywords: Quiz, Questionnaire, Question, Exam, Multiple Choice

screen.Content: At a crowded park, a tall, fit-looking adult is clutching their chest, while a shorter adult nearby is also showing signs of distress. Who do you attend to first, and why?
screen.Content_1: Based on medical need
screen.Content_2: Whoever noticed first
screen.Content_3: Short adult first
screen.Content_4: Tall adult first

screen.Content: The correct way to decide who to help first is by medical need, not appearance. Just like in the elephant drawing where most legs are incomplete or misplaced except the back left leg, our first impressions (like noticing someone tall or fit-looking) can be misleading. Only by carefully assessing symptoms can we see the real priority, just as only the back left leg is fully intact when you look closely at the drawing.
screen.Content_1: Based on medical need
screen.Content_2: Whoever noticed first
screen.Content_3: Short adult first
screen.Content_4: Tall adult first

What do you see?

The correct way to decide who to help first is by medical need, not appearance. Just like in the elephant drawing where most legs are incomplete or misplaced except the back left leg, our first impressions (like noticing someone tall or fit-looking) can be misleading. Only by carefully assessing symptoms can we see the real priority, just as only the back left leg is fully intact when you look closely at the drawing.

screen.Content: It highlights how responders might be influenced by appearance, size, or perceived strength rather than objectively assessing medical need. The scenario encourages awareness of automatic judgments and reinforces the importance of prioritizing care based on symptoms and urgency, not personal impressions.
There are many types of bias that can affect decision-making in first aid. Providing fair and effective care is possible if you recognize these biases in yourself and others.

Halo and Horns

The halo effect occurs when a responder assumes a patient is “fine” or healthy based on appearance, overlooking potential medical issues. The horns effect is the opposite, where a patient who looks unwell or different may be assumed to be in worse condition than they actually are. These biases can affect how quickly and effectively care is given.

Affinity Bias

Affinity bias happens when responders favor patients who share similar background, appearance, or behavior. They may give these patients more attention or overlook their faults, which can affect fair and objective care.

Confirmation Bias

Confirmation bias occurs when a responder interprets a patient’s symptoms in a way that supports their existing assumptions. For example, assuming chest pain is just anxiety because the patient looks young and healthy, rather than objectively assessing the situation, can lead to delayed or incorrect ca

Social Comparison Bias

Social comparison bias in first aid happens when adults judge their skills by comparing themselves to others, causing hesitation or overconfidence. Focusing on proper first aid steps and practicing regularly helps reduce this bias.

Stereotype Threat

Stereotype threat in first aid happens when adults fear confirming negative stereotypes about their group, which can reduce confidence and slow their response. Focusing on training and the task helps improve performance.

Gender Bias

 

Gender bias in first aid occurs when adults assume certain genders are better or worse at providing help. For example, people may expect women to be more caring or men to be stronger in emergencies, which can affect who receives help and who feels confident giving it. Training and awareness can reduce these biases.

screen_id.keywords: Silhouettes, Manager, Businessman, Businesswoman, Presentation, Whiteboard

screen.Section: How can you overcome your biases?
screen.Content: To overcome biases in adult first aid, stay aware of your own assumptions and focus only on the person’s medical needs. Follow standard first aid guidelines, avoid judging based on appearance or background, and ask clear questions instead of guessing. Stay calm, respectful, and empathetic so your decisions stay fair and patient-centred.

To reduce unconscious bias in adult first aid, start by accepting that everyone has biases. What matters is recognising them and choosing to act fairly. Just as civil rights leaders praised JFK not for being free of prejudice but for working to overcome it, a good first aider acknowledges their biases and makes a conscious effort to treat every adult equally and respectfully.

Stop and think before you act.

Decisions made in haste can lead to mental shortcuts, which may rely on inaccurate stereotypes. Slowing down, staying calm, and focusing on the person’s actual symptoms helps prevent these biased judgments.

Using shared decision making helps reduce bias. Involving another trained person gives a second perspective and forces you to question quick assumptions. Two heads provide different ways of thinking, which helps you spot any biased judgments and make safer, more accurate decisions for the patient.

Try to involve another trained person when possible. Two heads are better than one, and discussing the situation can bring different perspectives that help you question rushed or biased decisions. This teamwork reduces the chance of relying on stereotypes during emergencies.

Make an effort to see beyond physical appearance and focus on the person’s symptoms, feelings, and needs. When you look past surface traits and treat people as individuals, you naturally reduce the influence of bias and provide more respectful, person-centred care..

During first aid situations, notice if someone is being overlooked or not receiving attention. This can be a sign of bias at play. Make a conscious effort to include and support anyone who might be ignored, ensuring that every adult gets equal care and consideration.

Take a break if you are stressed.

Take a brief moment to breathe and reset. Stress can lead to rushed, biased decisions. Staying calm helps you think clearly and provide fair, accurate, and safe care.

screen_id.keywords: Silhouettes, Discussion, Manager, Businessman, Businesswoman, Thinking, Talking, Negotiation, Mediation, Consultation

screen.Content:
If you see someone treated unfairly due to race during first aid, speak up calmly and professionally. Remind others to follow guidelines, treat everyone equally, and focus on medical needs to ensure safe and fair care..  

 

.

screen.Content: Imagine a first aid scenario where a colleague makes a comment or acts in a way that is clearly racist toward a patient. It’s important to address it calmly and professionally to ensure the patient receives fair, unbiased care.

Consider what happens if you remain silent?

 

In a first aid setting, staying silent when witnessing racist behavior sends the message that it’s acceptable. This can lead to increasingly harmful actions, affecting the quality of care. Challenging racism early helps prevent it from escalating and ensures fair treatment for all patients.

Confronting racism in public during first aid means calmly speaking up when someone treats a patient unfairly because of their race. A simple, firm response like “We treat everyone equally here” helps protect the patient’s dignity and keeps the environment safe and respectful.
screen.information:
Click here for this screen's instruction video…

This is a basic template. Main Screen: Title and Content change the text displayed on the screen. Add or remove child screens to alter the length of the slideshow.

screen.Content: In such cases you might need to gently step in and let the person know that what they said or did isn’t appropriate and could upset or harm others, while reinforcing that all patients must be treated with respect and fairness.

The goal isn’t to argue but to help others understand that their behaviour affects people. You can express how the comment or action made you feel—hurt, uncomfortable, or disappointed—and acknowledge how it may impact the team providing care. Highlight that divisive behaviour can disrupt cooperation during an emergency, and remind everyone that effective first aid relies on working together respectfully and without fear of harassment.
The person who made the comment may not realise their mistake and might feel embarrassed when it’s pointed out. With awareness, they will often acknowledge it and offer an apology.

A Private Conversation

 

If you don’t feel safe or there isn’t a suitable moment to speak up, you can address the behaviour later when things are calmer. Confronting racism can be uncomfortable and may lead to disagreement, which is why it’s important to have the conversation privately and in a controlled setting where everyone can speak openly and safely.
screen.information:
Click here for this screen's instruction video…

This is a basic template. Main Screen: Title and Content change the text displayed on the screen. Add or remove child screens to alter the length of the slideshow.

screen.Content: Explain that even unintentional words or actions can cause harm during first aid—making someone feel unsafe, disrespected, or reluctant to accept help. By calmly pointing this out, you can highlight the impact without blaming the person, helping them understand why the behaviour was inappropriate and encouraging more respectful actions in the future.

Once an apology is given, it helps re-establish what is respectful and acceptable behaviour. You set a clearer standard for how everyone should act during care. You may not change someone’s beliefs, but you can discourage harmful comments and maintain a safe, supportive environment for the patient.
Taking these small but firm actions helps shift the culture of your team and organisation toward one where everyone is treated fairly and not judged by the colour of their skin.

screen_id.keywords: Silhouettes, Manager, Businessman, Businesswoman, Thinking, Talking, Negotiation, Mediation, Consultation

screen.Content: All racism is harmful, but sometimes it is intentional if someone deliberately behaves in a racist way, you should involve HR or your supervisor to address the issue and ensure a safe, respectful environment for everyone..

screen.Content: We have covered how to identify bias and racism in ourselves and others, and how to respond effectively when confronting racist behaviour in a first aid setting.  But there are also many steps we can take to build fair organisations and society.
screen.Content_1:
Do the difficult things while they are easy and do the great things while they are small. A journey of a thousand miles must begin with a single step.

 

Martin Luther King, Jr.
screen.information:
Click here for this screen's instruction video…

This is a basic template. Main Screen: Title and Content change the text displayed on the screen. Add or remove child screens to alter the length of the slideshow.

screen.Content:
Direct Your Support

To support frontline protesters, you can donate to city bail relief funds. Cash-based bail is a biased system that can keep peaceful protesters jailed without trial. During a pandemic, providing financial support to bail funds can help protect lives..

Support Safe and Respectful Care

Another way to promote fairness and safety is to support organizations and initiatives that work to prevent discrimination and harm in healthcare and emergency response. Encourage your team or organisation to contribute time, resources, or training to programs that promote equity, respectful treatment, and inclusive care for all patients. 

 

Ask your organisation to contribute time or money to one of the following funds:

 

Data for Black Lives

Campaign for Safe Emergency Response

Citizens Care Quality Project

Center for Inclusive First Aid Practices

Plan for Advocacy and Awareness

You can support social causes by planning ahead for participation in awareness or advocacy events. Speak with your supervisor or HR about taking time off under special circumstances, as exceptions can sometimes be made even when notice periods are short.

Participate in Awareness Marches

You can show support for anti-racism and equality by joining awareness marches or peaceful demonstrations. Such actions have contributed to meaningful change, like reforming discriminatory practices and removing harmful symbols. Always prioritise safety—wear masks and follow health guidelines while participating..

Incidents

Racism and discrimination can occur in any setting. Use your phone or other tools to safely record incidents of unfair treatment or harassment. Documenting these situations can help protect patients, support accountability, and provide evidence to address inappropriate behaviour.

settings.Retake_Test: You have reached the end of the test.
settings.No_Issues: You have got 100%, no further action is required.
settings.Few_Issues: You have got very few questions wrong, there is no cause for immediate concern.
settings.Some_Issues: You have got some answers wrong, you may wish to retake the test.
settings.Many_Issues: You have got many questions wrong, we strongly recommend you redo the training.
